Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: New Housing Design Models and Sustainable Urban Growth

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Already more than half the world lives in urban areas. As urban growth continues planning experts and government officials are working to design new models for housing and urban development that make more efficient use of public resources and create more livable cities. In particular, some experts are promoting "densification" through designing compact, higher-density housing as a way of creating a more sustainable city and fostering social integration. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, explores the impact of these sustainable design practices on urban governance, housing policy, and social relations. Understanding the societal impact of these new design principles is critical for developing better policies that will create more robust urban infrastructures, optimize public resources, and create a better quality of life for American citizens.

University of California, Irvine doctoral candidate Melissa Wrapp, supervised by Dr. Keith M. Murphy, will examine the implementation of principles of sustainable urban development in the context of public housing policy. The researcher asks how changes in the technical aspects of housing design impact the management of urbanization and shape social relations, both between residents and with local government. She will undertake twelve months of ethnographic fieldwork in Cape Town, which will involve extended participant observation and structured interviews with municipal urban designers, architects, and residents involved in public housing provision. The African continent is urbanizing at one of the fastest rates in the world. Because of South Africa's unique political and legal history, it has become an important site for active experimentation with urban policy. The research will be conducted in Cape Town, South Africa, where municipal officials have worked to implement densification policies since 2012. Cape Town has the most competitive property market in the country, and also has a reputation for being the country's most segregated city, making it an ideal site to situate this research. This study will provide a timely contribution to interdisciplinary social science research on the global issue of sustainable development and design, particularly in contexts of economic and social inequality. Findings will also increase knowledge of socio-cultural drivers in land use patterns and improve the execution of public policy in light of ongoing urbanization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Melissa Wrapp has completed research for her dissertation supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant, entitled “New Housing Design Models and Sustainable Urban Growth.” Her research explores the cultural practices and social relations that coalesce around emergent New Urbanist housing densification projects in South Africa. She spent twelve months in Cape Town conducting ethnographic fieldwork, which entailed: 1. participant observation at a nonprofit engaged in urban slum upgrading through collaborative design processes, in meetings with municipal urban designers, in grassroots community meetings regarding housing issues, in magistrate’s court cases, and in design expos and festivals;  2. semi-structured interviews with housing practitioners in the nonprofit sector, municipal officials, human rights activists, residents, and property lawyers; 3. surveying of residents in high-density dwellings in the Cape Flats townships; and 4. archival research at the Western Cape Provincial Archives and collection of lay archival materials regarding housing development and ownership claims. As an anthropologist working at the intersections of design and law, Wrapp was interested in understanding the impact of sustainable design principles on housing development and urban inequality in South Africa from a qualitative ethnographic perspective.

 

Wrapp accomplished the established goals of her NSF-supported research. The products that have resulted from this study include a forthcoming presentation at the annual American Anthropological Association conference in San Jose, California, in November 2018. The presentation, entitled “Incremental to Compliance: Deferment and Design in Cape Town”, reflects on a series of negotiations between municipal officials and housing practitioners around the design of an incremental slum redevelopment project. In analyzing these encounters, Wrapp illuminates the ways in which the imagined futures of the city, inflected by the specter of apartheid, impact the rendering of buildings and relations in the present, raising crucial questions about the delayed fulfillment of the promise of democracy and ongoing forms of structural violence. Additionally, this research has produced a book chapter for an edited volume on ethnographic methods (chapter accepted; book under review). Through conducting research with a grassroots housing rights organization in Cape Town, Wrapp has successfully shared emergent findings of this study with interlocutors in a key target population (low-income residents and shack-dwellers impacted by densification policies) in the context of biweekly community meetings. Findings were also communicated in the form of a formal report, written collaboratively with community members, to the director of the municipal housing department. Wrapp also served as the primary author for a grant on behalf of the local nonprofit where she conducted participant observation. The grant sought funding to support an informal settlement upgrading project in the township of Khayelitsha; producing the grant application involved convening focus groups with local community leaders, writing the grant, and participating in a collective editing process. Wrapp’s grant application successfully secured $70,000 in funds to support the project. Wrapp’s research in South Africa forms the basis of her dissertation (to be completed in Spring 2020), scientific articles, talks, and course plans. The dissertation is an important contribution to a number of disciplines, including anthropology, sociolegal studies, African studies, and urban studies.
